citeinfo.title: The StreamCat Dataset: Accumulated Attributes for NHDPlusV2 (Version 2.1) Catchments Riparian Buffer for the Conterminous United States: 2010 US Census Population Density

pubinfo.publish: US EPA Office of Research & Development (ORD) - National Health and Environmental Effects Research Laboratory (NHEERL)

descript.abstract:
This dataset represents the population density within individual, local NHDPlusV2 catchments and upstream, contributing watersheds riparian buffers based on 2010 US Census data. Densities are calculated for every block group and watershed averages are calculated for every local NHDPlusV2 catchment(see Data Sources for links to NHDPlusV2 data and Census Data).
This data set is derived from The TIGER/Line Files and related database (.dbf) files for the conterminous USA. It was downloaded as Block Group-Level Census 2010 SF1 Data in File Geodatabase Format (ArcGIS version 10.0). The landscape raster (LR) was produced based on the data compiled from the questions asked of all people and about every housing unit.
The (block-group population / block group area) and (block-group housing units / block group area) were summarized by local catchment and by watershed to produce local catchment-level and watershed-level metrics as a continuous data type (see Data Structure and Attribute Information for a description).
descript.purpose: These data were created in support of the US EPA’s National Aquatic Resource Survey (NARS) and Safe and Sustainable Waters Resources (SSWR) Programs. However, these watershed summaries of landscape data should have broad applicability for hydrological, geomorphic, or ecological modeling, management, and restoration. For details on EPA NARS and SSWR Programs see http://water.epa.gov/type/watersheds/monitoring/aquaticsurvey_index.cfm and http://www.epa.gov/research/progressreport/water.htm
descript.supplinf:
All code and scripts used to produce these data were written in the python or R programming languages and are freely available at ftp://newftp.epa.gov/EPADataCommons/ORD/NHDPlusLandscapeAttributes/StreamCat/Documentation/Code/ or https://github.com/USEPA/StreamCat
Glossary of Terms
Stream Segment: NHDPlusV2 line describing a section of contiguous stream or river between upstream and downstream tributaries (as depicted in USGS topographic quadrangles), except where the segment is a headwater or terminal stream .
Catchment (Cat): The portion of the landscape where surface flow drains directly to an NHDPlusV2 stream segment, excluding any upstream contributions.
Watershed (Ws): The set of hydrologically-connected catchments, consisting of all upstream catchments that contribute flow to any local catchment.
COMID: Unique identifier for each stream segment, and associated catchment, in NHDPlusV2. Watershed metrics describe entire area of all catchments that accumulate to the specific catchment based on the NHD PlusFlow table.
Riparian Buffer (Rp100): Spatial buffer of 100-m that was added to NHDPlusV2 stream network and NLCD water pixels. The buffers were used to spatially constrain calculations for some landscape metrics to within 100 meters of the riparian area.
Landscape Layer: Any geospatial layer from which we derived statistical summaries for both local catchments and watersheds. These landscape layers were comprised of several GIS formats, including vector (points, lines, or polygons) and raster.

idinfo.useconst: None. dataqual.lineage:
2014 Housing and population dataset downloaded from http://www.gisnuts.com/terra/BGSF1v10 , named SF1_F GDB_US_BLOCKGROUP.zip. Join SF1HOUBG and SF1POPBG tables from SF1_Summary geodatabase with TIGER blockgroup shapefile (tl_2010_US_bg10.shp). Create population and housing unit density grids as rasters using 'gdal_rasterize' tool. Cell size was set at 90x90 meters. Data source, date, units and resolution were recorded in a project tracking spreadsheet and verified.
2014 Projection of dataset verified as USGS Albers Equal Area Conic and projected if necessary
2014 Performed a visual inspection of dataset for gaps, edges other anomalous features. Verified how no-data values were represented and recoded values as no-data where appropriate (for instance, if no-data locations represented by 0's or -9999, these were converted to no-data values). +
2015 Created raster of riparian zones using NHDPlusV2 flowlines and NLCD water class (RiparianBuffer.py)
2014 Ran zonal statistics python script (StreamCat.py) to calculate zonal statistics for all riparian buffers within NHDPlusV2 catchments in each NHDPlusV2 Vector Processing Unit (VPU). Zonal statistics were perofrmed using either ZonalStatisticsAsTable, TabulateArea, or spatially joining vector point data to catchments. Each method applies to the type of landscape layer being evaluated, Continuous, Categorical, or Point. We also calculated the percent of each catchment that had coverage by a given landscape layer (i.e. was not null). These results are accumulated using the NHDPlusV2 flow table to summarize upstream catchment values and complete watershed values for the metric.
2014 Clean and standardize results of zonal statistics table from accumulation script / process (makeFinalTables.py). Clean up consisted of calculating mean value of metric per zone, renaming and sorting zonal statistics fields, and writing zonal results to .csv file.

enttyp.enttypd: Catchment and watershed level riparian area summary of US Census attributes.

attr.attrdef: Unique ID label to each catchment in NHDPlusV2
Area of the riparian buffer within the catchment measured in square kilometers.
% of the riparian buffer within the catchment that is covered by the landscape layer.
Area of the riparian buffer within the local catchment and accumulated upstream catchments composing the entire watershed (Ws) measured in square kilometers.
% of the riparian buffer within the watershed that is covered by the landscape raster.
Catchment (Cat) level summary of the density of population per square kilometer inside of the riparian buffer based on US Census block groups.
Watershed (Ws) level summary of the density of population per square kilometer inside of the riparian buffer based on US Census block groups.
